description: God Hand is the featured game of the 45th installment of Super Replay. Beginning with Episode 7 a second game; Asura's Wrath, was added to the Super Replay. This marks the first time since Resident Evil a Super Replay featured two games. Andrew Reiner is the host, with Joe Juba on the sticks. Joining them are Ben Reeves and Leo Vader.
The first episode of the God Hand Super Replay is titled "A Poison Chihuaha!?"
The second episode of the God Hand Super Replay is titled "A Free Trip To China".
The third episode of the God Hand Super Replay is titled "Yankee Doodle Dandy".
The fourth episode of the God Hand Super Replay is titled "I Hate It Here".
The fifth episode of the God Hand Super Replay is titled "Spicy Flavor".
The sixth episode of the God Hand Super Replay is titled "Frater".

The seventh episode of the God Hand Super Replay is titled "Asura's Wrath Ep 1". As joked about seriously talked about in the previous episode this replay switches from a God Hand playthrough to an Asura's Wrath one.
The eighth episode of the God Hand Super Replay is titled "Asura's Wrath Episode 2". As started last episode this episode continues the playthrough of Asura's Wrath.
The ninth episode of the God Hand Super Replay is titled "Asura's Wrath Episode 3". This episode continues the playthrough of Asura's Wrath.
The tenth episode of the God Hand Super Replay is titled "Asura's Wrath Episode 4". This episode continues the playthrough of Asura's Wrath.
The eleventh episode of the God Hand Super Replay is titled "Asura's Wrath Episode 5". This episode continues the playthrough of Asura's Wrath.
The twelfth episode of the God Hand Super Replay is titled "Asura's Wrath Episode 6". This episode concludes the playthrough of Asura's Wrath.
The thirteenth episode of the God Hand Super Replay is titled "Cherry!". This episode returns to God Hand after several weeks of Asura's Wrath. It features special guest Chris Kluwe.
The fourteenth episode of the God Hand Super Replay is titled "Poison Chihuahua Returns".
The fifteenth episode of the God Hand Super Replay is titled "A Casino Episode". This episode begins the three episode casino arc.
The sixteenth episode of the God Hand Super Replay is titled "Skippable". This episode continues the three episode casino arc.
The seventeenth episode of the God Hand Super Replay is titled "The Casino Episode". This episode ends the three episode casino arc.
The eighteenth episode of the God Hand Super Replay is titled "The Battle Of Clumsy Old Man".
The nineteenth episode of the God Hand Super Replay is titled "How To Poison Coworker".
The twentieth and final episode of the God Hand Super Replay is titled "The M.A.J.O.R. and the Minor: Part 2". This serves as both the season and series finale of Super Replay
Mega Man is the featured game in the 44th installment of Super Replay. Andrew Reiner is the host, and on the sticks is special guest Tim Turi. Joining them are Jeff Cork and Leo Vader.
The first and only episode of the Mega Man Super Replay, with special guest Tim Turi from Capcom.

Killer7 is the featured game in the 43rd installment of Super Replay. Andrew Reiner is the host, and on the sticks is Suriel Vazquez, who ranks Killer7 as his favorite game of all time. Joining them are Joe Juba and Leo Vader. Ben Hanson fills in for Leo in Episode 4. Jeff Cork fills in for Reiner in Episode 8. Special guest Goichi Suda joins the crew on a bonus episode.
The first episode of the Killer7 Super Replay is titled "What's On That Shirt?"
The second episode of the Killer7 Super Replay is titled "A Personal Joe Juba".
The third episode of the Killer7 Super Replay is titled "Top Five Dissections".
The fourth episode of the Killer7 Super Replay is titled "Dat Backside Smile".
The fifth episode of the Killer7 Super Replay is titled "The Potato Episode".

Vampire Hunter D is the featured game of the 42nd installment of Super Replay. It is the eighth 12/31 Super Replay.

Ape Escape is the featured game of the 41st installment of Super Replay. It is the first live Super Replay, airing on December 1, 2017 starting at 8 am central time. Long asked for by the Facebook Group, it was the reward for reaching the Extra Life 2017 goal.

The Super Replay for Ape Escape began and ended on December 1, 2017 and ran for one live episode. Super Replays of God Hand and Killer7 were announced at the end of this episode, the result of a tied poll on the OverBlood Facebook Group.

Star Fox 2 is the featured game of the 40th installment of Super Replay. The game was developed for the Super NES, but was released for the first time in 2017 with the Super NES Classic Edition. This Super Replay was technically released the day before the game itself released!
Comprised of only one 40-minute episode, this is the shortest "official" Super Replay to date.
The Super Replay for Star Fox 2 begins and ends with Andrew Reiner as host and features Jeff Cork and Ben Reeves.
Pokémon Snap is the featured game of the thirty-ninth installment of Super Replay. Previously a Replay, it was used in the final round in the Super Replay Showdown.

The game features 63 of the original generation of 151 Pokémon. It features 6 main sections (Beach, Tunnel, Volcano, River, Cave and Valley) and a bonus level (Rainbow Isle). The controller is passed between hosts Andrew Reiner and Kyle Hilliard per stage as they compete for the highest photo score.

The nightmarish Sonic the Hedgehog preceded this Super Replay. The emotional strain of it apparently necessitated an extended break from new games in the Super Replay series. This led to the latest start for a new Super Replay in a calendar year, with the first episode airing on July 31.
The Super Replay for Pokémon Snap begins with Andrew Reiner and Kyle Hilliard. Each swapping after a run.

After Reiner enthusiastically captures a 300 point Charizard the Valley level is unlocked. Kyle manages to get a stunning 50 point Dratini in his final run. The episode closes with 52 Pokémon captured.

description: The Super Replay for Pokémon Snap concludes with the fifth episode. Andrew Reiner and Kyle Hilliard both remain on, swapping after each run.

pok.c3.a9mon_captured_this_episode: For overall scores visit the main page.

The main focus of this episode were signs. Reiner captures Mewtwo in the first Cave run. Despite two hit and runs Kyle was able to capture Kingler in his Beach run. Little focus was put on photos leading to low overall scores throughout the episode. The next run to capture the Tunnel Pinsir sign saw Reiner get it on the vehicular bloodlust and attack an Electabuzz. Kyle quickly captures the Volcano Koffing sign in the following run. Reiner rushes through the River level and misses his sign but is allowed the Super Replay's first restart. The rough start mulligan pays off and the Cubone sign is captured. The final Valley level sees an immediate Dugtrio sign capture by Kyle unlocking the final level; Rainbow Cloud. The episode closes with Reiner capturing the Super Replay's highest score: an 8,500 point Mew.

description: Sonic the Hedgehog is the featured game for the 38th installment of Super Replay, continuing the 12/31 tradition of playing terrible games. This is the first 12/31 Super Replay without Tim Turi, so it's a departure from the survival horror games that are typically played on 12/31. This can be seen as a new beginning for the 12/31 Super Replay - moving on from OverBlood and games of its ilk, and expanding the definition of "bad" Super Replay games.
The first episode of the Sonic the Hedgehog Super Replay has Andrew Reiner, Kyle Hilliard, and Ben Reeves at the controls, with guest Joe Juba.

in_this_episode: Intro Cutscene: We start off watching the introduction, which introduces our main characters, Princess Elise (not to be confused with Elise Favis), Dr. Eggman, and our hero Sonic the Hedgehog. We also see a mysterious "white Sonic". Reiner tells us that Elise and Sonic will be making out in this game, so stay tuned. This intro cutscene reminds Kyle of Final Fantasy Kingsglaive.

Soleanna: Gameplay starts off in the open-world city of Soleanna. Here, they test out some shoes from Alberto Robert, in a mission called "The winder of a Shoemaker" (??). These shoes allow Sonic to enter the first level, Wave Ocean.

Wave Ocean: Sonic collects a bunch of rings, and rides a whale. Then Tails starts to shut the gate, to block the whale, but it only goes halfway down. The whale, however, gets the idea and backs off. During this level, we learn that Joe Juba never walks down hallways, on principle. What a weird guy.
Soleanna: Back to the city. Here we discover Sonic's alter ego, Sonic the Hedgehole (or Sonic the Asshole), who takes a soccer ball from a group of kids and kicks it into the ocean. What a jerk!

Boss Fight: Egg-Cerberus: Kyle finds himself getting emotionally attached to this giant creature, comparing it to The Last Guardian. However, it must be killed to continue with the story, so Kyle reluctantly "grinds the tail" and eventually slays it.

Dusty Desert: After some hilarious deaths, falling through the sand at high speeds, they discover how to get past it, and finish this mostly uneventful level. At the end, we're treated to a cutscene of Sonic and Elise slowly falling in love. Then Sonic forces her to run at an insane speed, almost tearing her arm off in the process. This episode ends with the dramatic reveal of Silver the Hedgehog, who vows to destroy Sonic for some reason.

description: The second episode of the Sonic the Hedgehog Super Replay has Ben Reeves, Andrew Reiner, and Joe Juba at the controls, with guest Kyle Hilliard.

in_this_episode: Boss Fight: Silver the Hedgehog: This is an absolute disaster. Silver keeps freezing Sonic in midair whenever he gets close, killing Sonic without any chance to fight back. They quickly look up a walkthrough and figure out the strategy. It's still terrible, but they manage to defeat him. Silver says that the Iblis Trigger must be destroyed, whatever that means. Amy is introduced. She holds off Silver, while Sonic goes after Elise.

Soleanna: Sonic decides to fight the Soleanna Boys, a group of little kids. Joe reveals that he has no problem beating up children in real life, as a grown man. What a weird guy. Sonic finds Pele, the Beloved Dog, and has to walk very slowly, which is a whole lot of fun. Sonic the Hedgehole breaks up a tea party with four identically dressed men, by attacking the men then running off. The soldiers in the city then put together a logic puzzle for Sonic to see if he is worthy. Okay guys. Then Sonic needs to find Knuckles for some reason. In the process, he gets a disk for some guy, with classified info on it, by "destroying all enemies in the New City". The crew discusses their plans for the Game Informer floating car, based on Joe's designs from 3rd grade. Joe is now Senior Magnetics Engineer. Sonic kills a bunch of robots, while the crew discusses Sonic the Hedgehole's favorite drink, Bag O' Blue Nuts. This is a hot, lumpy drink that comes in a bag, similar to Ben Reeves' favorite beverage, warmed-up old bowls of Rice Krispies. We find Knuckles, which is when Wade Wojcik chimes in to tell us that echidnas (like Knuckles) have a four-headed penis. He gets this information from penile scientist Dick Cocks. Thanks Wade.
White Acropolis: A terrible snowboarding level. This ends in failure, sending them back to a WAY earlier checkpoint to end the episode.

description: The third episode of the Sonic the Hedgehog Super Replay has Andrew Reiner, Kyle Hilliard, Joe Juba, and Ben Reeves at the controls.

in_this_episode: White Acropolis: Continues with the snowboarding from last time. We learn that Reiner farts when pressing buttons really hard. We also learn that Brian Shea is the densest and whitest material on Earth (with snow taking second place in both categories). Joe Juba, GI's resident snowman (because he knows a lot about snow and men), gets in a plug for his Sonic fan art, which reveals the color of Sonic's penis. What a weird guy.

Crisis City: We see a cutscene, in which Reiner admires Eggman's legs, and Sonic and friends are sent to the distant future. There they meet Shadow and Rouge. Then the level starts, with fire everywhere and raining cars. Reiner calls this level the biggest pile of Shea he has ever seen. Here, Ben Reeves reveals a few "Ben-ventions":
Pogrow Sticks - like pogo sticks that are also Chia pets
Ear Pugs - ear plugs that look like pugs
Garden Garb - a shirt you wear that has plants growing on it
After failing this level a few times (the final time, Sonic just kills himself before they even gain control), they decide to switch to Silver's episode for a while.
Crisis City (Silver Episode)

description: Illbleed was the featured game in the twenty-second installment of Super Replay. It premiered on December 30, 2013 and continues the 12/31 tradition of playing terrible games; despite being released a day early.  It featured Andrew Reiner, Tim Turi, Jeff Cork, and Dan Ryckert. It was created by Crazy Games (formerly known as Climax Graphics) the developers of the fifteenth Super Replay installment Blue Stinger.

Cyberia 2 was the featured game in the twenty-first installment of Super Replay. It premiered on November 16, 2013. It was hosted by Andrew Reiner, Tim Turi, Jeff Cork, Dan Ryckert, and Zach Pligge. It is the sequel to the thirteenth Super Replay installment Cyberia, a game made famous for just how much it frustrated Tim Turi.

The sequel improved almost nothing, and in some cases was actually worse than its predecessor. Although Tim still considers the original Cyberia to be the worst game he has ever beaten (which the crew was surprised with, as it looked to them like Cyberia 2 was worse), he was still quite frustrated by this game as well for very similar reasons, asking out loud in the second episode, "How does it suck so bad in so many similar ways to the original? How did they learn nothing!?" Dan Ryckert agreed, stating, "If you didn't have a walkthrough, this game would be unbeatable."

Mega Man Legends 2 was a Super Replay that ran from September 27, 2012 to November 8, 2012. It was hosted by Andrew Reiner, Dan Ryckert, Tim Turi, and Capcom employee Greg Moore. As with the first MML, Tim Turi was at the controls.
The Super Replay lasted thirteen episodes, one more than Mega Man Legends.

The first episode of the Cyberia Super Replay has Tim Turi at the controls with Andrew Reiner as host, with guests Dan Ryckert and Jeff Cork. This was the original crew to be featured on the Replay Roulette segment where Cyberia was discovered.

in_this_episode: The episode begins with Tim selecting medium difficulty for both arcade and puzzles (something that, in later episodes, the rest of the crew would urge him to reconsider).

Playing as a character named Zak, whose back-story is not given any mention in the game itself (but is detailed quite extensively in the instruction manual for some odd reason), the first part of the game takes place in an oil rig in the ocean, where Zak has to pick up a computer-automated fighter jet (or "trans-fighter") to fly to Siberia, Russia, where the final section of the game takes place, infiltrate a scientific research complex, and find a top-secret project called the Cyberia Weapon. Immediately upon arriving, a PA announcement tells Zak to "take the door on the right, and don't wander around."

Tim wanders around, though, and seven minutes into the game, he discovers the first instance of a recurring problem in Cyberia: just how easy it is to die without any warning. He is shot to death by a character that the crew notices bears a resemblance to Mike Ehrmantraut from Breaking Bad, so they refer to him as Mike henceforth.

Eventually, Tim goes through the correct door and progresses the story, defending the oil rig from an attack by operating a turret. Afterwords, Zak kisses a woman he met three minutes prior, causing the apparently jealous owner of the rig to take him hostage. In a scuffle, both he and the woman are killed, freeing Zak. Tim guides Zak through two shootouts, both of which are against people who look like Mike, and then disarms a bomb on the trans-fighter, which he then boards and flies away on.

It should be noted, however, that all of the above takes up most of the replay episode, largely because Tim dies over a dozen times due to various different causes without any sort of warning. These deaths include, but are not limited to: slipping on spilled oil, sticking Zak's hand in a barrel of burning acid, failing to disarm a bomb due to a laughably absurd-looking puzzle, walking off a suspended platform, and being shot to death by the stealthy and seemingly ever-present Mike.
The episode ends with a preview of what is to come: a series of rail-shooter levels, which Tim quickly comes to detest.

description: The second episode of the Cyberia Super Replay has, like the previous episode, the exact same crew: Tim Turi at the controls, Andrew Reiner as host, and with guests Dan Ryckert and Jeff Cork.

in_this_episode: In this episode, the trans-fighter begins its flight path on what was described in the opening scene of the game as the "optimal route" to the Cyberia complex. A rather odd description, considering that the optimal route apparently includes an entire military of bad guys in six separate locations. Inconveniently, the automatic weapons system fails, so while the flight is automated, the shooting isn't.

So, Tim is forced to suffer through six rail-shooting levels, five of which are featured in this episode. On top of not being particularly enjoyable, Tim notes that the D-pad is the only way of moving the firing cursor, making many of the levels incredibly frustrating to play. The most notable is the fourth one, which takes place in a short but narrow traffic tunnel containing both enemy forces and oil trucks that explode if shot even once. Because of how many enemies there are on screen at any given time, as well as the unresponsiveness of the D-pad controls, it takes the crew twenty minutes to beat, resulting in loud applause for Tim when he finally does. The episode concludes with a few short attempts at the fifth level.

description: The second episode of the Cyberia Super Replay has, like the previous episode, the exact same crew: Tim Turi at the controls, Andrew Reiner as  host, and with guests Dan Ryckert and Jeff Cork.

in_this_episode: This episode begins where the last one left off, at the fifth rail-shooting level. The trans-fighter stops for refueling, the animation of which is so overly simplistic that the crew finds it hilarious.

The sixth rail-shooting level--the final one before reaching the Cyberia complex--proves to be the most difficult for Tim, taking him a half hour to beat, and he often dies just before the final enemy. At one point, he gets farther than he has ever been before, leading Dan to shout incoherent but excited noises, which in turn causes the normally patient Tim to snap, "Dan, shut the hell up!" Although Tim apologizes soon after, and even Dan concedes that Tim should have yelled at him, by this point, the game has clearly taken a toll on Tim's sanity (to the comedic amusement of everyone around him).

The trans-fighter lands in a snowy mountain range a few yards away from the complex, and Zak disembarks, leading the crew to rejoice that they're back on the ground and don't have to suffer through more rail-shooting levels. Instead, they get into a shootout at the entrance of the complex with Mike--yet again--and suffer more hilariously unprompted deaths while trying to get into the complex (one of which is dying due to overly loud background noise).
The episode concludes with the crew unsure of what to do next, finding that the farthest door into the complex is guarded. By Mike. Again.

description: As with with the previous episodes, the crew remains the same: Andrew Reiner as host, with guests Dan Ryckert and Jeff Cork. Tim Turi is once again at the controls.

in_this_episode: The episode begins with the crew making a few more attempts to get further into the complex, but Tim eventually concedes that he has no idea what he's doing. Finally, they figure out that they confused a door for a wall, and unknowingly unlocked it in the last episode. They progress through it, only to get in a shootout with four Mikes.

After successfully getting through that, they access video messages ("V-mail") from employees who used to work at the complex before being killed, and the crew laughs at how hideously ugly the sub-par graphics make most of them appear. They also experience the oddity of going through a sleeping quarters and watching Zak merely say, "Hmm..." when he sees a pair of boxers.

Further in, they sneak up on two Mikes who are gathering information about the Cyberia Weapon. A shootout ensues with one of the Mikes...again...and they access a password-protected computer to look at more V-mail. Not sure of what to do next, they go back the way they came, only to be hilariously killed when another Mike pops out of an elevator and throws a flash grenade at Zak. The episode ends after a few fruitless attempts to get past this particular Mike.
The highlight of this episode is probably the fact that, a little over forty minutes into this episode, Mike's actual name is revealed to be Arnold, but the crew is talking too loud to hear it.

description: As with with the previous episodes, the crew remains the same: Andrew Reiner as host, with guests Dan Ryckert and Jeff Cork. Tim Turi is at the controls.

in_this_episode: The episode begins where the last one left off, with the crew trying to get past the Mike who is throwing a flash grenade at them. Tim remarks that Overblood, which the crew previously held up as "the worst game ever" really doesn't deserve that title, because Cyberia has turned out to be far, far worse.

Eventually they discover that a seemingly insignificant series of shapes they found on a V-mail file is in fact a password to lock the elevator that Mike keeps popping out of. They shoot Mike before he can lob the flash grenade at them, and then lock him in. The flash grenade goes off inside the elevator with the doors closed, killing Mike and allowing Zak to move on.

The problem is, the crew has no idea what to move on to, because the game gives them no indication. They stumble around until they discover that Mike is absent from another area of the complex that he previously guarded. They explore that area (after being killed by a separate Mike, who suffocates Zak by turning on a room's halon system without warning). After getting in another shootout with another Mike, they access a computer terminal and open the vents to a room where a dead man is being kept, making it possible for them to obtain a card key to move on to the next are of the complex. Unfortunately, before they can, they find themselves in yet another shootout with two more Mikes. Fortunately, these prove to be the final Mikes they have to deal with in the game.
The episode ends with them using the card key they found to get into another room.
memorable_quotes_from_the_crew: Tim (stunned after a flash grenade, normally used for blinding and deafening an enemy, instead explodes and consumes Zak's body): I am....what?......I'm so happy I'm playing this with people, otherwise I'd have no idea what was real......WHAT!?

description: Like the previous episodes, the crew remains the same: Andrew Reiner as host, with guests Dan Ryckert and Jeff Cork. Tim Turi is once again at the controls, despite his increasingly stronger wishes that he wasn't.

in_this_episode: This episode resumes with the crew verbally hoping that this is will be the last episode of the Cyberia Super Replay. It won't be.

Starting in the room that they got access to by using the card key, they access a terminal and watch two V-mails, but they don't listen carefully enough to determine what they're supposed to be doing. Eventually, they look up a guide that says a horrible virus has spread throughout a section of the complex up ahead, and that while three vaccines exist, they've all been contaminated, and need to be at least 72% decontaminated by means of a nano-probe in order to be usable. Upon activating the nano-probe, the crew discovers, to Tim's utter horror, that the decontamination process takes the form of...
...Another rail-shooting level.
After many tries and several deaths from traveling into the contaminated area without a usable vaccine, Tim manages to decontaminate a vaccine, and Zak successfully immunizes himself.

Going further into the complex, the crew laughs hysterically when they open a door and, without any warning, a small creature flies through and begins eating Zak's face, resulting in yet another hilariously unprompted death. They access a nearby computer terminal and learn that flesh-eating creatures called nanites (although the crew calls them "face-huggers") have infested the final area of the complex before the Cyberia Weapon. The only way to solve the problem is to send in a remote probe called Charlie, equipped with an electricity gun, and destroy every single one of the face-huggers.

This process is, once again, a rail-shooter. And this time, it's arguably the most difficult one of all due to the fact that literally every single face-hugger that appears on screen has to be destroyed. There is a shockwave device installed to kill face-huggers that manage to fly off-screen, but it needs to be used within 2-3 seconds of the face-hugger escaping, and it uses up a significant amount of Charlie's energy. As a result, Tim suffers many losses due to Charlie shutting down.
The game ends with Tim realizing the true horror of what he must endure to complete the game.
memorable_quotes_from_the_crew: 1) Tim (upon realizing that the vaccine decontamination sequence is a rail-shooting level): Does a rose by any other name still smell like s***?
2) Tim (after dying from the first face-hugger): Oh God....what IS this GAME!?
3) Tim (after realizing that he really does have to kill every face-hugger): Oh my GOD...
Dan (laughing at Tim's misery): Oh NO...
Tim: Do you know what this MEANS!?
4) Dan: We should get [Cyberia creator] Drew Markham to fly out here for our Cyberia 2 Super Replay.
Tim: That actually would be amazing.
Tim: Force him to play it.
Reiner (to Markham): Look what you did!

description: Andrew Reiner hosts, with Tim Turi at the controls, and Dan Ryckert and Jim Reily as guests.

in_this_episode: This episode picks up with Tim making another attempt at completing the rail-shooting level that is the Charlie probe sequence, which he first began in the previous episode. It is this sequence, perhaps more so than any other in the game, that nearly breaks the normally patient Tim Turi's sanity for good. He simply finds himself unable to complete the sequence, despite turning the brightness all the way up, enlisting the help of his guests to memorize where the face-huggers will appear, and ignoring pleas from Reiner and the guests to decrease the difficulty level. Tim goes through a hell that most people wouldn't wish on their worst enemies, drudging through a grueling 38 minutes of failed attempts (even longer if one counts the few attempts made in the last episode).
Finally, Tim's salvation arises in the form of a beautiful suggestion: using a mouse instead.

The crew did not initially think of that because they didn't think they had a mouse that would be compatible with a Playstation, but once they realize that they do, they plug it in (after switching from a PS3 to a PS2 because the mouse wasn't compatible), and Tim finds himself empowered with the lightning-fast movement and sensitivity that the mouse affords him. It still takes him a few tries, but after 10 minutes, he finally completes the Charlie probe sequence.

The crew finally gets to the Cyberia Weapon's chamber after one last incoherent puzzle. Upon seeing what they think is the Weapon--some sort of speaking object that looks like a giant silver walnut with a purple gem--Zak gets a transmitted message from his boss, who reveals that Zak is, in fact, the real Weapon. The crew laughs at how stupid the plot twist is, and proceed to merge Zak with the Weapon as per the game's story, creating one of the most awkward-looking things the crew has ever seen (with Dan remarking that the result looks like a waffle iron). The merged Zak and Cyberia Weapon then fly off into space for the final showdown with Zak's boss.
A rail-shooting level.
The episode ends after Tim attempts the level two times.
memorable_quotes_from_the_crew: Tim (upon seeing Zak merged with the Cyberia Weapon): This is....this is the worst s***....

description: The final episode of the Cyberia Super Replay has Tim Turi at the controls, and Andrew Reiner as host, with guests Dan Ryckert and Jim Reily (declared "the savior of the last episode" due to his suggestion that Tim use a mouse).

in_this_episode: In this final episode, the crew watches as Tim guides the merged Zak/Cyberia Weapon (which they have dubbed "the Flying Space Waffle") to a space station where Zak's boss, revealed to be the true antagonist of the game, is residing. One final rail-shooting level ensues, in which the Flying Space Waffle destroys the station. In effect, Tim manages to do something he has wanted to do for some time: beat the game.

...Only to find out that the game glitches right after he made the last shot by still having enemies appear on screen even as the final cut-scene begins. He instinctively shoots back, which freezes the game. Tim then realizes that he has to do the level all over again in order to truly beat the game and see the ending. He does manage to beat it a second time, managing to prevent the glitch by not firing back at the enemies that appear when the final cut-scene begins.

............Only to find out that there was literally about eight seconds left of the cut-scene after the point at which his game froze, consisting merely of a brief shot of the Flying Space Waffle burning up in the atmosphere and then crashing into a horribly-rendered mountain. The final insult is that there's not even an after-credits ending sequence.
The credits roll, with Tim vowing revenge on every name that pops up.
memorable_quotes_from_the_crew: 1) Tim (after seeing how brief and unsatisfying the ending is): There is....there is literally more of an epilogue in Mario 1!
2) Tim (after the glitch happens): God, even when you BEAT the game, it's still Cyberia!
3) Reiner (upon completing the game): We probably...took ten years off of Tim's life.

quotes: Dan: "You wouldn't be scared of that? If you turned on CNN tomorrow and a robotic Hitler had been reanimated? You wouldn't be concerned about that?"

description: Half-Life is the featured game of the eleventh installment of Super Replay. It was scheduled to premier in the first week of April 2012, but was delayed due to technical issues and a magazine deadline. The first episode eventually aired on May 3, 2012.
Dan Ryckert picked Half-Life as his game for Super Replay Showdown, and is hosting the Super Replay and playing the game.

Episode 1 is the debut episode of the Half-Life Super Replay.  After many delays (much like Valve) the episode aired on May 3, 2012.  This episode features Dan Ryckert (on the mouse and keyboard), Andrew Reiner, Tim Turi, and Ben Hanson.  In this episode Dan plays through the first three chapters (Black Mesa Inbound, Anomalous Materials, and Unforseen Consequences) and gets a fair way through Office Complex with the episode ending when Dan receives his first grenade.

OverBlood 2 is the featured game of the tenth installment of Super Replay. It premiered on December 31, 2011 and ended on February 23, 2012 with episode 20, making it the longest Super Replay (as of August 2012). It continues the 12/31 tradition of playing terrible games established with it's prequel OverBlood. It is the most anticipated Super Replay to date, due to the popularity of the OverBlood Super Replay.

Prior to the airing of the Super Replay, knowledge began to circulate among the OverBlood fanbase and Game Informer staff of a glitch affecting some copies of OverBlood 2 which caused the game to freeze during a certain cutscene, leaving the player unable to progress and therefore unable to complete the game. Game Informer's copy did not include this glitch; however, the crew "faked" the glitch at the end of Episode 5.
